author: By Sam Roberts
title: Marion Joseph, Citizen Warrior on Reading Instruction, Dies at 95
description: Arguing for phonics as a learning tool and getting results, she exerted influence on educational policy in California and beyond.
content: Marion Joseph, whose concern about her grandson’s struggles as a first grader propelled a back-to-basics approach to teaching reading in California and elsewhere in the country, died on March 24 at her home in Walnut Creek, Calif. She was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: An Update to the California Playlist
description: The latest additions to our ever-evolving soundtrack include “Beverly Hills” by Weezer and the Jerry Garcia Band’s “Mission in the Rain.”
content: Today I’m back yet again with updates to the California Soundtrack, our project that tries to capture the essence of the Golden State in a single playlist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Russian Gas, Acid Rain and Industrial Scaremongers
description: Why you can’t trust economic advice from big business.
content: In yesterday’s column I highlighted Germany’s infuriating unwillingness to wean itself from Russian gas, something that would be costly but not devastating to the nation’s economy. Part of my point was the hypocrisy: Germany was willing to demand almost inconceivable pain from southern European countries that, the Germans claimed, had borrowed irresponsibly — but is unwilling to accept far smaller penalties for its own feckless policy of relying on Russian energy, despite decades of warnings about the risk this policy created.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lois Smith Brady
title: Soon After Meeting, Attending Parenting Classes
description: Chrystina Crown and Nathanael Thompson, who met on Hinge more than two years ago, bonded over a commitment to become foster parents.
content: Soon after Chrystina Moritz Crown and Nathanael Robert Thompson met on the dating app Hinge in December 2019, she invited him to go on a road trip from Colorado to California via the Grand Canyon with her and three of her friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Roger Cohen
title: ‘La French Tech’ Arrives Under Macron, but Proves No Panacea
description: The president has brought innovation, jobs and growth. Still, resentments fester on the eve of the presidential election.
content: PARIS — In full Steve Jobs mode, President Emmanuel Macron of France donned a black turtleneck in January and took to Twitter to celebrate the creation in France of 25 “unicorn” start-ups — companies with a market value of over 1 billion euros, or almost $1.1 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A DHL Cargo Plane Breaks in Two Landing at a Costa Rica Airport
description: No one on board was injured, a spokesman for the delivery company said, adding that it was working with the authorities to remove the plane.
content: An airport near Costa Rica’s capital was temporarily closed Thursday after a DHL cargo plane split in two during an emergency landing, officials said. No one was injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Sweeping Basquiat Show Curated by His Sisters Offers Intimate Look at the Artist
description: The exhibition at the Starrett-Lehigh building in Chelsea features more than 200 artworks and artifacts from the collection of the artist’s estate, most of which have never been seen.
content: In a grainy home movie from 1968 — well before he had started on the path that led him to art world fame and an untimely death — an 8-year-old Jean-Michel Basquiat, dressed smartly in long shorts and a button-down shirt, gently guides his year-old sister, Jeanine, by the hand in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, with his 4-year-old sister, Lisane, frolicking in the grass beside them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tiger Woods Has an Up-and-Down Day at the Masters
description: Woods had four bogeys in his first five holes on a blustery afternoon. He recovered enough to play on into the weekend, but it might be tough to catch the leader, Scottie Scheffler.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — An hour into his second round at the Masters Tournament on Friday, Tiger Woods looked baffled. A poor chip on the first hole had led to a bogey. He squandered a chance at birdie on the par-5 second hole with middling pitch. He missed a makable downhill par on the third green.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
title: ‘The City Lives’: With Russian Forces Gone, Kyiv Starts to Revive
description: The anxiety remains, but in Ukraine’s capital, large lines of cars are now forming on highways into the city and businesses are reopening.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — On Feb. 25, the day after Russia invaded Ukraine, Kolya Rybytva gathered his grandmother and younger sister and left Kyiv “quickly and without unnecessary sentiments,” he said, heading west. His parents and brother stayed behind to help in the war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: How Important Is Mindfulness to Your Daily Life?
description: Do you practice meditation every day? What else do you do to feel calm and grounded?
content: How do you cope when you feel stressed, sad or overwhelmed? Have you ever practiced meditation? Is it important to your daily or weekly mental wellness?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Penelope’ Review: Adrift Between Ithaca and Progress
description: A new musical-comedy retelling of “The Odyssey” from the York Theater Company tries to center a powerful woman but feels like a show about and for men.
content: For 20 long years, Penelope has waited for her husband, Odysseus, to sail home to Ithaca from the Trojan War. He was forced to go in the first place, but now the fighting has been finished for a decade and still he stays away — a king seemingly forsaking his kingdom and his queen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Power Remains Out for More Than 400,000 Customers in Puerto Rico
description: The island’s fragile electrical grid was slowly recovering from its latest loss of power, potentially caused by a failed circuit breaker.
content: Days after an islandwide power failure struck Puerto Rico, in the latest breakdown of a perennially troubled electrical grid, more than 400,000 customers remained in the dark on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian J. O'Connor
title: Staying the Course May Be the Key to Wartime Investing
description: Experts say investors should resist the urge to make drastic changes to their portfolios because of global turmoil.
content: Entire sectors of the global economy are in turmoil after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, leaving investors worried about how they should react. Should they buy energy stocks? Shares of defense contractors? What about agriculture? Is it time to go to cash?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Ketanji Brown Jackson Has an ‘African’ Name. I Wish We Knew More About It.
description: Its unspecified origin leaves a linguistic shoe undropped.
content: In March, The Times’s Erica L. Green reported that Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s parents chose her name from a list “sent by an aunt who was serving in the Peace Corps in West Africa.” As Jackson explained in opening remarks at her Supreme Court confirmation hearing: “When I was born here in Washington, my parents were public school teachers, and to express both pride in their heritage and hope for the future, they gave me an African name, ‘Ketanji Onyika,’ which they were told means ‘lovely one.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: The Biggest Promoter of Mexico’s Presidential Recall Election? The President.
description: The vote has the potential to upend the country’s political system. But many fear it will amount to nothing more than a tool for propaganda.
content: MEXICO CITY — Strolling through Mexico’s capital these days, it would be easy to assume the country’s president is at imminent risk of losing his job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a ‘Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ Tour Guide Spends Her Sundays
description: Stephanie Windland takes fans of the show around in a vintage car to visit the sites of 1950s New York.
content: “I love meeting people. I love costumes. And I love performing,” said Stephanie Windland, an actress who works as a guide for the Marvelous Mrs. Maisel Sites Tour. With her current gig, she gets to “talk about two things I adore: the show and this city.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: The Real Rock Stars Were the Brides and Grooms
description: Sixteen couples from across the country were married onstage during a three-day rock festival in Oklahoma City, and five others renewed their vows.
content: By the time the last drum kit was pounded and the final tattooed singer strutted off the stage at Honeymoon Rock Fest in Oklahoma City, 16 couples from across the country had been married before thousands of screaming fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Miller
title: Germany Reckons With Wagner: Cultural Jewel, or National Shame?
description: A new exhibition at the country’s national history museum examines the strong feelings stirred by its most famous 19th-century composer.
content: BERLIN — Few composers inspire such a mix of appreciation and disgust as Richard Wagner. Especially here in Germany — where Wagner’s work is understood as a combination of national cultural jewel and national political embarrassment — the composer’s work is laden with meaning and interpretation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conrad de Aenlle
title: The Shifts in the Markets Are Enough to Make Your Head Spin
description: After falling sharply for weeks, the stock market recovered much of its lost ground, though bonds have kept falling. With major risks unresolved, there may well be worse to come.
content: The shocks from soaring inflation, rising interest rates and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent markets plunging for weeks. Stocks recouped much of their losses, but both markets have looked shakier in the last few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Globalization Is Over. The Global Culture Wars Have Begun.
description: We’re entering the age of red world versus blue world.
content: I’m from a fortunate generation. I can remember a time — about a quarter-century ago — when the world seemed to be coming together. The great Cold War contest between communism and capitalism appeared to be over. Democracy was still spreading. Nations were becoming more economically interdependent. The internet seemed ready to foster worldwide communications. It seemed as if there would be a global convergence around a set of universal values — freedom, equality, personal dignity, pluralism, human rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Republicans and Democrats Agree Child Care Needs Help. Here’s How They Differ.
description: In a new bill, Republican senators adopted many of the Democrats’ goals, but they remain far apart on elements like how to pay for it.
content: The crisis in child care has become a rare issue of bipartisan agreement. Democrats are trying to revive their plan to subsidize child care for most families, and now Senate Republicans have introduced their own bill on the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Benveniste
title: The American Crossword Puzzle Tournament Was a Family Reunion
description: Families, couples, crossword constructors and die-hard solvers gathered for the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, a tradition since 1978.
content: After two years of pandemic-fueled isolation, hundreds of competitive crossword solvers eagerly flooded a hotel ballroom filled with rows of tables, chairs and yellow folders to prevent cheating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Stoop to New Heights With These Sidewalk Furniture Hunters
description: New York City curbs are awash in discarded furniture that can liven up your home or make you some money. We talked to some experts on how to find it.
content: A few weeks ago, Denise Gordon was walking near her Gramercy home when she spotted an antique chest of drawers on the curb. She didn’t need it, but this dresser was too good to ignore — solid wood, with clawed feet and dovetail joinery. It was also too heavy for Ms. Gordon, who is 68, to carry. So she did what any good sidewalk stooper would do: She offered two random men on the street $20 apiece to carry it back to her apartment. And, being New Yorkers, they did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Will Sell Its Long-Awaited Cybertruck Next Year, Elon Musk Says
description: Delays in producing the pickup have allowed rivals like Ford to beat Tesla to market with electric pickups.
content: Tesla will begin producing its much-delayed electric pickup, the Cybertruck, next year along with numerous other new products, Elon Musk, the carmaker’s chief executive, said late Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Gray
title: International Bonds Can Give Your Investments a Smoother Ride
description: The bond market is reeling, recording its worst performance in decades. International bonds might help your portfolio ride out the turbulence.
content: International bonds can baffle even experienced investors. Add to that the fraught state of the world, with warfare and a pandemic, and it’s little wonder many people shy away from them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Alabama Governor Signs Ban on Transition Care for Transgender Youth
description: Legal challenges are being prepared against the law, which is one of the most restrictive in the country and threatens doctors and nurses with up to 10 years in prison.
content: Gov. Kay Ivey of Alabama signed legislation on Friday that prevents medical professionals from providing care that aids transgender young people in transitioning, adopting some of the country’s most restrictive measures and threatening doctors and nurses with up to 10 years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: The Most Flavorful Easter Ham Starts on the Stove
description: Want to avoid a dry ham? Wary of too many boiled eggs? Genevieve Ko has solutions for two common Easter entertaining challenges.
content: At the chef Gabriel Kreuther’s New York City restaurant, reclaimed wood beams ringing the dining room evoke the timber homes of Alsace, a French region bordering Germany. Mr. Kreuther grew up there, on a farm where he and his family slaughtered one pig a year and preserved many of the parts, including the hind legs, which they cured into ham.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Lauren Hirsch
title: Spirit Airlines will weigh JetBlue’s takeover offer against its planned merger with Frontier.
description: Spirit made the announcement two days after JetBlue’s unsolicited bid to take over the company.
content: Spirit Airlines said on Thursday that it would enter talks with JetBlue Airways about a bid to combine the two companies, a deal that threatens to spoil Spirit’s plans for a merger with Frontier Airlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: Go Ahead, Count Naomi Osaka Out
description: Sometimes you deliver your best performance when your back is against the wall.
content: Naomi Osaka doesn’t usually follow pretournament chatter before she hits the court, but last month was an exception. One evening she heard a former rival of hers, Caroline Wozniacki, analyzing the lineup for the Miami Open on TV and predicting who would advance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K. Takes a Hawkish Lead on Russia, but Will Europe Follow?
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson is pressing European allies to take a hard line, like cutting off Russian energy imports, but after Brexit, his influence is limited.
content: LONDON — When Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain welcomed Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany to 10 Downing Street on Friday, the two men worked hard to avoid echoes of Margaret Thatcher’s famous admonition to President George H.W. Bush three decades ago, “This is no time to go wobbly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Marjorie Taylor Greene Calls the Police on Jimmy Kimmel
description: Kimmel said of Greene’s angry tweets about a joke he made earlier this week: “She’s a snowflake and a sociopath at the same time — a ‘snowciopath.’”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Not Even LeBron James Could Save the Lakers
description: The team that was built to be unbeatable just kept losing.
content: On Jan. 25, the Los Angeles Lakers went to Brooklyn to face the Nets and displayed a joyfulness that was unusual for them this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: A low-cost, low-tech climate solution that saves lives
description: Early warnings systems for extreme weather can sharply reduce death tolls when storms hit, and they don’t need to be complicated.
content: How do you save lives in an era of cascading climate disasters? You warn people of the dangers approaching. You give them time to get out of harm’s way — and a place to take shelter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: The Electric Car Market Heats Up
description: Soaring fuel prices and climate change concerns are driving demand for the vehicles in Australia, as elsewhere. But they are particularly hard to find here.
content: Secondhand cars listed for tens of thousands more dollars than new cars. Batches of vehicles selling out in minutes. Monthslong wait times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh and Rose Wong
title: How Long Do Symptoms Last? When Should You Test? A Covid Timeline.
description: Having Covid can be a wildly confusing experience. But you can still make a plan to get through the course of illness.
content: The highly contagious subvariant of Omicron, known as BA.2, has prompted concern among health officials as it becomes the dominant version of the coronavirus around the world. So far, signs suggest that BA.2 is 30 to 80 percent more transmissible than the original version of Omicron, and cases are already going up in several states across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Bullock and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: That’s the Spirit!
description: Caitlin Reid’s puzzle clues are a master class in misdirection.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Let’s talk about misdirection. It’s one of my favorite tactics in crossword puzzle cluing but can be confusing to those who are not used to thinking about what else a clue can mean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Schwarz
title: Transforming Britain From Brutality to Gentleness
description: Simon Heffer’s “High Minds” traces the impact of reformers on industrial Britain, and the beginnings of the welfare state.
content: HIGH MINDSThe Victorians and the Birth of Modern BritainBy Simon Heffer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alwa Cooper
title: In This Joana Choumali Work, a Dreamy, Swallow-Filled Sky
description: The artist used photography, fabric and paint in a reinterpretation of a sunrise that she witnessed in Dakar, Senegal. The work is also a tribute to her mother.
content: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at “The Return of the Swallows” (2021) by Joana Choumali, whose work is the subject of “It Still Feels Like the Right Time,” an exhibition on view at Sperone Westwater in New York through April 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joy Dong
title: Many Shanghai residents say Covid lockdown measures have caused food shortages.
description: The authorities have locked down the city of 26 million in a bid to contain China’s worst outbreak since the pandemic began.
content: Before Guan Zejun’s apartment block was locked down on March 27, he bought enough noodles and bread to last a week. He figured that if he ran out, he could always order in. After all, this was Shanghai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Why Does a Hair Braider Need a License?
description: Such requirements raise entry barriers to professions that can disproportionately affect racial minorities.
content: Peter Q. Blair is the youngest of seven sons and “got his start understanding markets by selling fruit and vegetables in the Bahamas in the Nassau Straw Market with his brothers,” according to the website of Harvard’s Graduate School of Education, where he is an assistant professor. He studied math and physics at Duke and Harvard before circling back to markets, earning a doctorate in applied economics at the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton School.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Jury Reaches Partial Verdict in Trial of Men Accused of Plot to Kidnap Michigan Governor
description: The judge told jurors to continue trying to reach agreement on other charges where they have deadlocked.
content: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — After deliberating all week, jurors said Friday morning that they had reached a verdict on several charges in the trial of four men accused of plotting to kidnap the governor of Michigan but that they were deadlocked on other charges. The judge told them to continue deliberating to try to reach agreement on all counts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Nakate
title: This 900-Mile Crude Oil Pipeline Is a Bad Deal for My Country — and the World
description: Africa isn’t just a victim of the climate crisis; it’s also a place where infrastructure decisions will shape how it unfolds.
content: KAMPALA, Uganda — This week, the panel of climate experts convened by the United Nations delivered a clear message: To stand a chance of curbing dangerous climate change, we can’t afford to build more fossil fuel infrastructure. We must also rapidly phase out the fossil fuels we’re using.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Organization Can Keep Operating N.Y.C. Golf Course, Judge Rules
description: New York City lost a court battle over its attempt to cancel the Trump Organization’s contract to operate a public golf course in the Bronx after the riot at the U.S. Capitol.
content: The Trump Organization can continue to operate a city-owned golf course in the Bronx after a judge ruled on Friday that New York City had wrongly terminated the company’s contract following the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Russia Cuts Interest Rates to 17 Percent as Ruble Recovers
description: The unscheduled change came after the ruble had regained most of its losses since Russia invaded Ukraine.
content: Russia’s central bank said on Friday that it would cut its interest rate to 17 percent, from 20 percent, starting Monday amid signs that financial stability risks in the country were easing thanks to capital controls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Their ‘Great Chemistry’ Felt More Than Just Friendship
description: Roxanne Werner and Kristina Nichols met three years ago while they were both working for the county clerk in Houston.
content: When Roxanne Leigh Werner and Kristina Jean Nichols met as colleagues in January 2019, both sensed the potential for a deeper connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Rayfield Wright, Cowboys’ Hall of Fame Lineman, Dies at 76
description: He was an All-Pro right tackle in the 1970s. But in retirement he was diagnosed with dementia, which he linked to repeated hits to the head.
content: Rayfield Wright, a tough, agile Hall of Fame offensive tackle for the Dallas Cowboys who was on five Super Bowl teams in the 1970s, then suffered from dementia for at least a decade, which he believed was most likely caused by repeated blows to the head, died on Thursday. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: You May Not Find Many Friends on This Power-Hungry Supreme Court
description: But large corporations and right-wing activists will have a majority of justices almost certainly on their side.
content: The confirmation of Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court on Thursday was as noteworthy for what it didn’t change as for what it did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Hollywood Gets a New Giant
description: The blockbuster merger of Discovery and WarnerMedia closed on Friday, putting many of the biggest names in movies, TV and news under one roof.
content: Discovery, the medium-size media company that began as a small cable network in 1985, has completed something once unthinkable: assuming ownership of a fabled Hollywood company that controls Batman, Harry Potter, “Sex and the City,” “Game of Thrones,”  CNN and March Madness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Gerda Weissmann Klein, Honored Holocaust Survivor, Dies at 97
description: Her story was told in an Oscar-winning documentary, and her message of hope and love in the face of overwhelming evil was an inspiration to millions.
content: Gerda Weissmann Klein, whose harrowing story of survival through a series of concentration camps and a 350-mile death march during the Holocaust became the subject of an Oscar-winning documentary, and whose advocacy for tolerance and civic education won her a Presidential Medal of Freedom, died on Sunday in Phoenix. She was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Nancy Wartik
title: Returning to the Office, but with Scars
description: Both employees and employers may face mental health issues as offices reopen.
content: As more workers return to their offices, many are bringing deep emotional and mental scars from the pandemic to their cubicles — and at a time when the world feels particularly unstable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: A 4-Year Degree Isn’t Quite the Job Requirement It Used to Be
description: New research finds companies are starting to rely less on the college filter in hiring. But it remains an obstacle to opportunity for many.
content: As a middle school student in New York, Shekinah Griffith saw a television news report of President Barack Obama visiting an innovative school in Brooklyn. Its program included high school, an associate degree in a technical subject, an internship and the promise of a good job.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fiction About Lives in Ukraine
description: The critic Jennifer Wilson discusses new books by Yevgenia Belorusets and Andrey Kurkov, and Ben McGrath talks about “Riverman.”
content: While a steady stream of disturbing news continues to come from Ukraine, new works of fiction highlight the ways in which lives there have been transformed by conflict. On this week’s podcast, the critic Jennifer Wilson talks about two books, including the story collection “Lucky Breaks,” by Yevgenia Belorusets, translated by Eugene Ostashevsky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: As Gas Prices Went Up, So Did the Hunt for Electric Vehicles
description: Prices at the pump have apparently given some Americans second thoughts. But two practical problems remain: not enough cars and relatively few charging stations.
content: Thinking about buying an electric car? You’re not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Lockdowns in China Block Truck Shipments and Close Factories
description: China’s Covid lockdowns and restrictions are holding up truck drivers who carry crucial components among factories and take products to ports, posing a new disruption to the global supply chain.
content: BEIJING — China’s mounting Covid-19 restrictions are creating further disruptions to global supply chains for consumer electronics, car parts and other goods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett
title: Russian Blunders in Chernobyl: ‘They Came and Did Whatever They Wanted’
description: Tank treads ripped up the toxic soil, bulldozers carved trenches and bunkers, and soldiers spent a month camped in — and dug into — a radioactive forest.
content: CHERNOBYL, Ukraine — As the staging ground for an assault on the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv, the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, one of the most toxic places on earth, was probably not the best choice. But that did not seem to bother the Russian generals who took over the site in the early stages of the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Why Do We Yawn?’
description: In this lesson, you will learn about what happens in our bodies when we yawn and investigate the question of whether yawning is contagious.
content: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Ex-Goldman Sachs Banker Convicted for His Role in a $4 Billion Fraud
description: Roger Ng is most likely the only person who will face trial in the United States in connection with a scheme to loot billions from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund.
content: A former Goldman Sachs banker was convicted Friday on bribery and money-laundering charges stemming from a globe-spanning fraud scandal: the looting of more than $4 billion from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Officials Say Russian Art, Seized by Finns, Should Return Home
description: Finnish custom officials had seized the art several days ago, but the Finns and European Union officials decided that art lent to museums for exhibit did not come under sanctions.
content: Finland’s foreign ministry said Friday that it had authorized the return of three shipments of Russian art that had been on loan to museums and galleries but were impounded by Finnish customs officials on their route back to Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Fiona Hill on Whether Ukraine Can Win — and What Happens if Russia Loses
description: The foreign policy expert maps out the possible futures for the Russia-Ukraine war.
content: The Russia-Ukraine war has changed considerably in recent weeks. Vladimir Putin is no longer talking explicitly about regime change in Ukraine. The Russian military has shifted its focus away from taking Kyiv and toward making territorial gains in Ukraine’s east. The prospect of an outright Ukrainian victory is no longer out of the question. And negotiations between the parties over a possible settlement appear to be making some progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Stella Tan, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Jessica Cheung, Chelsea Daniel, Patricia Willens, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: How Germany’s Approach to Russia Backfired
description: German leaders believed that more trade would help ensure peace in the region. The war in Ukraine has revealed why that theory was flawed.
content: Thirty years ago, Germany put forth a theory for how to work with Russia. Major energy deals, leaders argued, would keep Russia from going to war with its neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner and Johnny Milano
title: For the Yankees, a Nice Win Comes After a Crushing Blow
description: In a day of mixed emotions, Aaron Judge ended his negotiations for a contract extension but the Yankees got a walk-off win over the Boston Red Sox in extra innings.
content: It was all set up for Aaron Judge to own the day. Two outs, bottom of the ninth, tie game on opening day in the Bronx. Judge comes to bat and rips a line-drive double into the left field corner. He’s got to trot in with the winning run, right? Surely that would happen next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks union campaign pushes on, with at least 16 stores now organized.
description: Workers at six more stores in upstate New York have voted to unionize.
content: Starbucks workers have added to the momentum of a union campaign that went public in late August and has upended decades of union-free labor at the company’s corporate-owned stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: A Chinese Concerto and a Romantic Classic Gaze Back
description: The New York Philharmonic, under Long Yu, played works by Rimsky-Korsakov, Qigang Chen and Rachmaninoff at the Rose Theater.
content: The New York Philharmonic played Russian music on Thursday, for the third week in a row. It was yet another argument against President Vladimir V. Putin’s claims that his country’s culture is being canceled in the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and John Ismay
title: Land Mines on a Timer, Scattered Over a Ukrainian Town

Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan, eliminate her security detail and perhaps touch off a civil war. But after a trial in which prosecutors portrayed the four defendants as threats to democracy, jurors on Friday acquitted two of the men and said they were unable to reach verdicts for the two others.

content: The spectacle created by Republican senators with presidential ambitions as they browbeat the first Black woman nominated to the Supreme Court — after which 47 Republicans voted against her on Thursday — might have seemed like glaring evidence that the G.O.P. had written off the Black vote this November.

content: Something Genevieve Ko, a deputy editor and columnist here in Food and Cooking at The New York Times, always says is that a combination of textures is an essential aspect of a delicious dish. Crunchy and creamy, chewy and runny, crisp and tender: Part of cooking is learning how to play ingredients off each other in interesting and appealing ways. (And it doesn’t stop with texture, of course. Think of the push and pull of flavor in sweet-and-sour sauce, or the mingling of hot and cold in an ice cream sundae with warm fudge sauce.)

He had visited a Duane Reade during his lunch hour and loaded up on candy to assuage his stress, or so I imagined. There are worse vices.

She was taking a short break from rehearsing “The Handmaid’s Tale” — the first production at English National Opera she is directing since taking over its artistic leadership in the middle of the pandemic. Her presence on the carpet and interactions with guests, where she mixes her natural charisma with a personal warmth, have made her stand out, despite having limited experience as the interviewer, not the interviewee.

content: ACROSTIC — This puzzle is a feat in themed cluing. I think you could make a case for every entry’s connection to the passage (although OBLIQUE could be a bit of a stretch). The passage is from a science book written for a mass audience called “Rain: A Natural and Cultural History,” by Cynthia Barnett. The book explains precipitation on a global and local scale (apparently there’s a village in India that gets 39 feet of rain per year), which explains the deluge of aquatic-themed clues and entries. The passage itself involves geography and the phenomenon of airflow over and away from the hot equatorial zone, which explains the smattering of ethereal references, like CHINOOK and AEOLIAN, as well as the cartographic trivia.
